c74object.name: fl.filtertags~
c74object.digest: Filters tagged frames using a set of specified tags
c74object.description: The filtered output contains any items from the input that match the given tags. The residual output contains any items from the input that do not match the given tags. The number of tags can be set explicitly by parameter. Alternatively, it can be set implicitly by the tag parameters present at instantiation.

entry.name: /num_filters [int]
entry.description:
INSTANTIATION ONLYSets the number of tags.
(default: 1)

objarg.name: tag_01...10
objarg.description:
Arguments set parameters tag_01...10:
Sets tag number N [1-10].

method.name: info
method.description:
Print info about fl.filtertags~ to the max window for reference purposes. If no arguments are provided then all information is posted to the Max window. Else a set of flags is used to select which sections of the reference to display, and whether or not the information should be provided in a shortened form.
The following flags are available:
description - display the object description.inputs - display info on inputs.outputs - display info on outputs.io - display info on both inputs and outputs.parameters - display info on the object parameters.quick - display shorten versions of any info displayed.

method.name: frame
method.description: Used internally by FrameLib's connection routines. User messages have no effect.

method.name: sync
method.description: Used internally by FrameLib's connection routines. User messages have no effect.

attribute.name: rt
attribute.description:
Sets the realtime state for fl.filtertags~. When set to 0 fl.filtertags~ forms part of a non-realtime network for performing offline processing in Max message threads. This mode of operation uses buffer~ objects for audio IO.
More info on non-realtime processing with FrameLib can be found in Tutorial 11.

attribute.name: id
attribute.description:
Sets the context name for fl.filtertags~ in order to determine distinct processing contexts.
More info on FrameLib contexts can be found in Tutorial 10.
